summaryText: Pastor Scott Williams delivered a powerful, transformative sermon about dropping the things that hold us back from experiencing God's full blessing! Using the story of Bartimaeus from Mark 10, he shared three critical things we need to 'drop' to see breakthrough: our cane (what we project to others), our coat (our comfort zones), and our cup (the things we're holding onto that prevent God's blessing). Scott's message was raw, real, and packed with personal stories that brought the biblical narrative to life. He challenged listeners to stop living for others' approval, get out of their comfort zones, and truly trust God. One of the most impactful moments was when he shared the story of Lando, a troubled juvenile offender who transformed through education and Jesus' love. The sermon culminated in a powerful altar call where hundreds responded to give their lives to Christ. Pastor Scott reminded us that the only thing that can truly fill our void is Jesus - not relationships, money, or temporary fixes. The message was a wake-up call to drop whatever is holding us back and fully surrender to God's plan.
mainPoints: Drop your cane: Stop worrying about what others think
Drop your coat: Get out of your comfort zone
Drop your cup: Let go of things preventing God's blessing

versesMentioned.text: Then they came to Jericho. As Jesus and his disciples, together with a large crowd, were leaving the city, a blind man, Bartimaeus (which means 'son of Timaeus'), was sitting by the roadside begging. When he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to shout, 'Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!' Many rebuked him and told him to be quiet, but he shouted all the more, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!' Jesus stopped and said, 'Call him.' So they called to the blind man, 'Cheer up! On your feet! He's calling you.' Throwing his cloak aside, he jumped to his feet and came to Jesus. 'What do you want me to do for you?' Jesus asked him. The blind man said, 'Rabbi, I want to see.' 'Go,' said Jesus, 'your faith has healed you.' Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus along the road.

Pray for the peace of Jerusalem: 'May those who love you be secure. May there be peace within your walls and security within your citadels.' For the sake of my family and friends, I will say, 'Peace be within you.' For the sake of the house of the Lord our God, I will seek your prosperity.
I will bless those who bless you, and whoever curses you I will curse; and all peoples on earth will be blessed through you.
Comfort, comfort my people, says your God.
For Zion's sake I will not keep silent, for Jerusalem's sake I will not remain quiet, till her vindication shines out like the dawn, her salvation like a blazing torch.

Monday.scripture: Jeremiah 29:11: 'For I know the plans I have for you,' declares the Lord, 'plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future.'
Monday.focus: Identifying areas where you're living for others' approval instead of God's purpose
Monday.action: Make a list of decisions you've made based on others' expectations. Pray over each one, asking God to reveal His true purpose for your life.
Monday.prayer: Lord, reveal the areas where I'm living to please others instead of You. Give me courage to follow Your plan, not the expectations of people around me. Amen.

Tuesday.scripture: Philippians 3:13-14: 'Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.'
Tuesday.action: Do one thing today that makes you uncomfortable. This could be having a difficult conversation, trying something new, or stepping out in faith in a way you normally wouldn't.
Tuesday.prayer: God, give me the courage to step out of my comfort zone. Help me trust You more than I trust my own fears and limitations. Amen.

Wednesday.scripture: James 1:6: 'But when you ask, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind.'
Wednesday.action: Make a list of your current challenges. Next to each one, write a faith-filled declaration about how God can transform that situation.
Wednesday.prayer: Father, increase my faith. Help me to believe in Your ability to work miracles, even in the most challenging situations. Strengthen my trust in You. Amen.

Thursday.scripture: 2 Corinthians 5:17: 'Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here!'
Thursday.focus: Letting go of past hurts and limitations
Thursday.action: Identify one thing from your past that you're still holding onto. Write it down, then symbolically 'drop' it by throwing the paper away or burning it, declaring God's freedom over that situation.
Thursday.prayer: Lord, I release this burden to You. Thank You that You make all things new. Help me walk in the freedom You've provided. Amen.

Friday.scripture: Proverbs 3:5-6: 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.'
Friday.action: Spend time in prayer, asking God to reveal any areas where you're trying to control outcomes instead of trusting Him.
Friday.prayer: God, show me where I'm holding onto control. Help me surrender completely to Your will and trust Your perfect plan. Amen.

Saturday.scripture: Romans 12:2: 'Do not conform to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God's will is—his good, pleasing and perfect will.'
Saturday.action: Fast from social media and spend that time reading Scripture, journaling, and listening to worship music. Reflect on how your thought patterns might be influenced by the world rather than by God.
Saturday.prayer: Lord, transform my mind. Help me see things from Your perspective and not from the world's. Renew my thinking and align my thoughts with Your truth. Amen.
